titlestmt.subtitle: An inventory of the collection at Syracuse University
titlestmt.author: MRC

list.item: 25 April 2011 - added material and updated the finding aid (CEG)
04 Sept 2012 - added material, removed misc printed material to Plastics Product Literature Coll. and updated finding aid (SDG)
2 Oct 2015 - Plastics Industries Technical Institute material added, M15-050 (MRC)
19 Sep 2019 - issue of "Plastics & You" transferred to cataloging; photograph, posters, DVD, calculators added (MRC)

did.head: Overview of the Collection
did.abstract: Miscellaneous items relating to the history of the plastics industry and notable figures in plastics research, development and manufacturing. Includes printed material, photographs, technical papers, interviews, and audiovisual material.

bioghist.head: Biographical History
bioghist.p: In 2008 the National Plastics Center & Museum in Leominster, Massachusetts transferred the majority of its holdings to Syracuse University's Special Collections Research Center (SCRC). The collections include more than 40 manuscript collections from organizations and individuals, as well as several thousand plastics artifacts. The Plastics History Collection includes miscellaneous materials not directly associated with those other collections but pertinent to the history of plastics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents of the Collection
scopecontent.p: The Plastics History Collection is comprised of a range of materials relating to the history of the plastics industry and support organizations and notable individuals.
Documentaries and training films consists of recordings of varying length on Bakelite, polyethylene, and other plastics-related topics. Formats include film, VHS, and DVD.
Exhibitions contain materials related to the National Plastics Exposition, ranging from the 1960s to the 2000s, and several posters on the history of plastics.

Interviews and biographies consists of biographies of and interviews with members of the "Plastics Pioneers," notable figures in the industry. The Plastics Pioneers Interviews were originally recorded in 1952 on 1/4" reel tapes (now at the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American History), and were digitized onto ten CDs by the donor.
Photographs contain images of machinery and products related to Dupont and Star Manufacturer Co.

Professional organizations contain printed material from the Plastics Historical Society, the Society of Plastics Engineers, the Society of the Plastics Industry, and the University of Massachusetts at Lowell.
Technical papers contains professional papers written by engineers on plastics molding and materials.
Miscellaneous contains awards, bibliographies, and miscellaneous printed/produced items, including manufacturing calculators and material on Monsanto's "House of the Future."

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: Alphabetical by subject and chronologically within a folder.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Other general plastics-related collections include the Plastics Artifact Collection and the Plastics Product Literature Collection. For a complete listing of all plastics-related collections held by &scrc_name;, please refer to &subjindex;.

&scrc_name; also maintains a comprehensive website which provides historical information on companies, products and individuals. The website serves as a portal for access to digital images of artifacts, print materials, company histories, finding aids for our manuscript collections, and more. Please visit the Plastics Collection website at http://plastics.syr.edu.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: One issue of the SPI publication Plastics & You (spring 1989) has been transferred to Rare Books for cataloging with other issues. Please refer to &summitref; to locate this item.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The majority of our archival and manuscript collections are housed offsite and require advanced notice for retrieval. Researchers are encouraged to contact us in advance concerning the collection material they wish to access for their research.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Written permission must be obtained from SCRC and all relevant rights holders before publishing quotations, excerpts or images from any materials in this collection.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation for this material is as follows:

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Majority of collection, and unless otherwise noted below, gift of Glenn Beall, 2010-2019.
Other items, gifts of various donors as noted in the inventory below.

note.p: Dates given are, as well as can be determined, the original recording dates of the productions. Some items were transferred to DVD in 2010 by &scrc_name;. Items without a box number are individually barcoded and should be requested by ID number.

did.abstract: documentary about Leo Baekeland, discoverer of Bakelite in 1907

did.unittitle: All Things Bakelite: The Age of Plastic [disc 1 of 2]

scopecontent.p: Commercially-produced historical dramatization of Baekeland's life and work. Contains both the full film (59 min.) and an "educational/industrial" condensed version (21 min.)

did.unittitle: All Things Bakelite: The Age of Plastic [disc 2 of 2]
did.abstract: extra content

scopecontent.p: Contains official movie trailer; lecture by Katarina Posch, interviews with Nancy Byck Welsh, whose father worked for Baekeland; interview with Loretta Gardner, a Bakelite Co. employee; a short feature on the Embed Art Co. who created the first Bakelite jewelry

did.abstract: documentary by Stan Sherer, about the Pro-phy-lac-tic Brush Company; includes interviews, archival footage
recreation of events; features many employees of Imperial Chemical Industries, ltd. who were involved in the discovery and subsequent production and development

features styrofoam produced by the DOW Chemical Company

Orroth, Jr. Assistant Professor, Department of Plastics, Lowell Technological Institute, Lowell, Massachusetts; old can label; post-it note that reads: "Old Du Pont training tape, 2004.55". Du Pont slogan: "Better Things for Better Living ... Through Chemistry"

did.abstract: includes photocopy of old label, partially cross out and illegible text; note on old reel reads: "New York Management Center"; additional note attached to old can reads: "Inside Polypropylene JCM NPCM, Kosy Collection??"
includes cameo by plastics expert Jeff Meikle and some comments on plastics' impact on the environment

did.unittitle: To Shape Tomorrow / The Fourth Kingdom

scopecontent.p: "To Shape Tomorrow" follows "befuddled Mr. Bagshot" throughout his day, highlighting how different his life would be without plastics. Produced sometime in the 1930s, the film promotes the wonderful things that could be made by the then-new processes of shell molding, thermoforming, laminated Formica, extrusion of PVC pipe and sheets, and the molding of phonograph records.
"The Fourth Kingdom" is billed as "the birth of the age of plastics."

Teachers' guide (29.5 minutes), to provide a clear understanding of the basic process used to convert molding materials into finished products. Prepared by the University of Wisconsin-Stout and also distributed by the Milwaukee SPE. In addition to plastics processes, it considers the history and growth of the plastics industry, problems relate to the disposal of discarded plastics, and some of the advantages of using plastics in the manufacture of many consumer products.
